history.content:
“Normally”? No. Google/Apple, for example, are both continuing remote work through  the end of the year, so at the very least, in person info sessions/career fairs are most likely off the table.

Fortunately, online info sessions are easy. Unfortunately, hiring freezes/furloughs/layoffs mean that there are just fewer jobs available. There will still be companies hiring, but I would expect to see a reduced number of more competitive positions (to what degree is impossible to know).

If you do decide to take a gap year/semester, I’d encourage you to try and spend it working in your field (internship/co op/freelance/major personal projects/open source contributions) to gain relevant experience.

children.subject:
Well, most hiring for Summer 2021 takes place in the Fall of 2020, and so if there's a hiring freeze at companies then I'd expect there won't be applications released in the fall, and if there's a slowdown expect to see fewer openings and more competition per opening. However, in the off chance things look up / we discover a miraculous cure, companies might ramp up hiring during Spring 2021. 

In other words, it's probably not a good time to be a sophomore or junior right now.
I'm just banking on my big N company giving me a return offer lol

Sure, but not everybody will have that opportunity. Plus, even those who get return offers won't be able to negotiate if they can't get those super inflated offers from the likes of Lyft and Airbnb, as well as paper money startups.
Poet, I would avoid banking on it if you can. If anything, be extra aggressive with your recruitment efforts, and try to set yourself up with backup options.
From what I've heard, the hiring slowdowns are only in effect for 2020. Internship/full time roles are starting in summer 2021. How likely are those jobs going to be effected?

My guess is that it would vary by the company. Those that are heavily affected by the coronavirus shutdown (e.g. Uber, Lyft, Airbnb) are likely to make significant changes to previous hiring practices. Those that aren't as heavily affected (e.g. Google, Facebook) are likely going to be closer to what they did in previous years.

Agreed with Atom. Unfortunately even some big N (ie Google) have already announced hiring freezes through 2020. Perhaps that will change by Spring, but I wouldn’t count on it.

Scale, regarding “insider info”, that legitimately doesn’t exist. CEOs themselves are also reacting to the constant changes - they don’t know any better than you what the economy will look like in 6 months, when a vaccine will happen, whether or not herd immunity will work, etc. We’re all in the dark, sorry :(
Does anyone have any insider info on whether internship recruitment in summer 2021 will be normal?

Yes. Work experience is very very important. If you’re unable to obtain a paid internship, I’d look for the following: paid contract work, open source software contributions, personal side projects (go further than just a personal site, build something interesting), or relevant research work (paid or unpaid). Any of those will allow you to practice your skills and have something to talk about on your resume/in interviews.

Unfortunately, I am already on a gap year, and I spent most of the year working on strengthening my coding skills, doing open source contributions, freelancing, and personal side projects (recently did few COVID-19 related ones). My goal for the end of this year was to land an internship. My resume is much stronger now and I'm re enrolling Fall 2020 as a junior. (I really want to take classes now and learn more advanced CS topics.) Perhaps my preparation provides me with a head start, but how do I prepare for recruitment in this mess? Honestly, I've been cold applying to job openings online on websites such as LinkedIn. But been rejected or ghosted every time, so I figured doing it the proper way such as going to career fairs and connecting with hiring managers and recruiters will increase the chances. But now with COVID-19, parameters are really messed up and I'm kinda worried. I've searched hopelessly on Reddit and GitHub for advice and hiring information, but it seems like a lot of companies are still on hiring freeze. If I wait more and COVID-19 situation gets better by Spring 2021, would it be too late for recruitment? If everything seems like bad timing, I think I should invest my time into studying and preparing to apply for a Masters or PhD program...

Some thoughts or advice would be greatly appreciated on how yall are going to approach recruitment this academic year for a summer 2021 internship.

Helix it sounds like you’re in a relatively good spot. I’d keep focusing on applications and interviews. If you’re not landing interviews, definitely get someone to review your resume. Otherwise, just keep working on it - that’s all you can do. Regarding spring, I would imagine there will be more positions available by then, but it’s impossible to know for sure. I think a masters or PhD is worth it for its own sake, but not necessarily just for money (it has a high time cost).

For juniors in particular, this might be the last time before applying for full-time jobs.  Any advice on this scenario?  I feel like a lot of us without work experience will be set back because those whose internships haven't been cancelled will have an upper leg.

history.content: I’m paying international student tuition, and I’ve finished most of my major requirements. I’m a sophomore. If tech companies don’t recruit this fall for summer internship next summer, I’m thinking of taking a gap year, because I think at this stage finding an internship in summer of junior year is very important and I can’t afford not having it.
history.subject: Will tech companies recruit normally this fall?
